reviewText: When you take into account that this is a direct-to-video movie shot on a much smaller budget than similar genre flicks, this is actually a pretty decent, gritty action film.  If you're expecting superb special effects, Oscar-winning performances, and top-name stars, look elsewhere.  "Sinners and Saints" is a modern day homage, or perhaps a tricked-out throwback, to the violent rogue cop films of the 1970s.  With a bit less gore, more implied violence, and less fashionable street clothes, this could easily have passed as a "Dirty Harry" film.A number of reviewers have touched on the torture and gore in the film.  It's strong stuff, to be sure, but I've seen a lot worse.  Be warned, though, that this is not really "date night" material.  That said, you get a convincing performance from Johnny Strong in the lead with a host of extended cameos from the better known stars.  Tom Berenger gruffs his way through a few quick scenes as Strong's boss and mentor, Sean Patrick Flanery cusses constantly while struggling to maintain a decent New Orleans accent as Strong's troubled brother, and poor Jolene Blalock delivers in a single but powerful scene as Flanery's junkie girlfriend.While there's virtually no re-play value in "Sinners and Saints," you could do a alot worse for a Friday night rental. It's brisk, gritty, and action-driven with plenty of bullets and blood for an evening of mindless, harmless entertainment.
summary: A decent, gritty action flick
Title: N/A

reviewText: This wasn't a paricularly bad movie, but not one that I'd ever need to see again.  There's nothing special about its story, its the same cops/robbers type repeatedly done, which is not per se a problem, but it certainly offers nothing inventive.  Overdone concepts are ok if they're at least entertaining, and this movie is at least somewhat entertaining.  My issues are over acting and production values.  For the most part, no really recognizable faces are used, and their inexperience really shows - meaning the acting is weak.  Its not horrible, but there's quite a few scenes where the bad acting becomes noticable (but not quite grating either).  The production values were odd though.  At times the film felt big budget, with grandiose and big attempt shots, but they ultimately fell short.  It kept feeling like the director was trying to achieve too much with creative camera work, while not really nailing the fundamentals.  Creative camera work cannot make up for weak acting other other basic issues, and that's where my primary issue with this film lies.  Probably worth a rental, but I would not advise a blind buy.
summary: Fun, but not particularly special
Title: N/A

reviewText: Great movie from the start to finish with some of the best gun fight scenes I have seen in a movie in a really long time. These scenes just blew us all away with how intense they were and how well they were being directed. If you love high amount of action and nonstop action then this film is perfect for you! Please be aware of the high amount of adult language being used in this film and the adult content: intense gun/blood/shooting scenes. I even found certain parts to be funny, for example in one of the most intense gun fights in the movie one of the bad guys gets shot up and all he can say is "F Psycho Cops" the entire time... hubby and I looked at each other and started to laugh so hard for it was true he is a psycho cop and they all better watch out because he is coming for your ass. Now this movie is not all about the shootout scenes, even though they are awesome, the storyline is great and the cast of characters perfect. Well rounded movie that hubby and I enjoyed from the very start all the way to the end. Highly recommend to everyone who loves good action films that take it all the back to the basics of great storyline and fun shootouts.
summary: Loved it from start to finish

reviewText: I will admit I went into this movie with not a huge amount of expectations. I knew it was an action movie set in New Orleans. Beyond that I didn't know anything about it.After watching it, I know it was a smaller budget movie but - aside from all the fancy special effects there isn't much difference.It's your typical action packed, lots of guns, a few explosions, linear plot movie. But, if you set your expectations for what the movie is. It's actually a pretty solid movie. Don't expect huge plot twists that will leave you slack jawed.But, expect a nicely done plot, that leads to some interesting moments.After all was said and done. I enjoyed it and have recommended it to a couple other people.

reviewText: Sinners and Saints follows a generally common theme among cop shows, but it's very entertaining nonetheless. The handsome gritty cop, with a troubled past (in this case a sad past) with no restrictions but lots of tattoos and a good heart, who can go around shooting and killing bad guys indiscriminately with a chief who only reluctantly attempts to restrain him. Hollywood through and through.But..... this was a very entertaining movie! Brutal, fast, and lots of action. The bad guys are really bad, and the good guy? .... even badder! He disposes of criminals like trash, and of course he does it with flair.A pretty cool movie in an old west kind of way and a definite surprise if you like action movies. The theme is certainly nothing new, and the underlying plot was puzzling, but the characters (not the acting), the action, and pace all blend well enough to keep you thoroughly entertained.If you like shootouts, very bad criminals taken down by an even badder cop, and intense action all around, then you'll like this movie....I did.
summary: Old theme, but very intense!
Title: N/A

reviewText: In the opening scene, this film looked like it was going to be a standard police procedural.  But after a few minutes, it evolved into a non-stop action packed affair, with one gun battle after another.  It seemed that almost everyone owned an assault weapon and the landscape quickly became filled with bullet riddled and charred bodies.  The film is set in post-Katrina New Orleans and it has a grittiness that made the entire City look like a war zone.There are two warring factions and Detective Sean Riley, played by Johnny Strong, is assigned to figure out what is going on and to bring the hostilities to an end.  Strong and the rest of the cast do credible job in their roles.The plot is predictable, but has some major loopholes.  For example, the hostilities by one faction are directed by a Russian mafia type boss, but we never really learn what his interest is in the outcome.  By the end of the film, nearly all of the bad guys (and some of the good guys) are dead, but the Russian boss apparently survives and is never heard from again.The real stars of this movie are the never ending gun battles and unarmed combat.  They are well choreographed and seem realistic and the special effects are good.  I like action films, but it was really hard for me to become immersed in this one, because the flying bullets and dead bodies became so pervasive that the movie lost all contact with reality.
summary: Guaranteed to Keep You Awake

reviewText: I really enjoyed this film. There was a lot of attention to detail as compared to alot of big buck action movies. I agree with the first couple of reviews more or less. You would be better off renting or buying this movie as opposed to most of the the high budget shoot em ups.  The lead Actor Johnny strong does a great job and was a solid lead character actor. I really hope to see more of him in the future. This film was a lot of fun to watch and my wife even really liked it (which is rare for a lower budget film as she is very picky). Granted there is nothing really new in this film but it was all actually done very well. Some of the editing is a little sketchy but overall It was a really good effort.  Highly recommended.
summary: Really Good Action Flick!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Sinners and Saints" was a pleasant surprise. Is it a b-movie? Without question. It houses a bunch of actors you've never heard of but do a good job and some you may have heard of like mostly T.V. actor Costas Mandylor. Judging the movie for what it is, it can only hit a certain threshold and it gets pretty close. The movie isn't without flaw, but it certainly makes the most of the appealing aspects of multiple weapons being fired on a viewing audience.First of all, the title of the movie, "Sinners and Saints" is pretty bad. There are no "Saints" in this movie. In fact, nobody comes even close with the exception of Detective Sean Riley's (Johnny Strong) 2nd partner Detective Will Ganz (Kevin Phillips). That being said, who really cares? I mean, we want to see bullets and death right? Well, you get it in spades. You get college kids set a fire, gunfights every 2 minutes, houses exploding, more people set on fire, and in between the gunfights you get more gunfights or maybe just a single bullet to the skull of somebody who didn't see it coming or somebody stepping on a bullet riddled body. As far as action movies go, you don't get cheated.In fact, there's so much action, that you start to wish you were watching the news on the day or two that this movie takes place, just to see all the gunfights going on in town. Part of the story should have been people fleeing the war zone to safer cities.My biggest problem with the movie though was the obvious comparisons to numerous cop and buddy/cop movies of the past. There are so many references to other movies that I almost lost count. The two main cops are an obvious comparison to Mel Gibson & Danny Glover's Lethal Weapon characters. There is even a birthday party with Riggs/Riley characters feeling out of place, leaving the room and having a nice conversation with his partners wife. Dirty Harry also shows his influence as well.This is a good movie. I won't deny that, I just wish it had a little more uniqueness and less copy cat. When you watch a movie and can't help thinking of a far superior movie because of it's similarities, it only makes you wish you were watching "Lethal Weapon" instead. The building of characters and the quality of the superior film, remind you that "Sinners and Saints" is no "Lethal Weapon".
summary: Somebody watched Lethal Weapon, Dirty Harry and lots of other great action movies

Not really I mean I liked it enough to watch the whole thing and try to figure out why the bad guys are motivated to be bad was interesting. Plenty of gun fights & carnage! Now the gunfights are epic and they had that kind of heat feeling to them (and by he I mean that at the gunbattle that was in that movie) the ones in this are different kinds of guns and they definitely blow some holes in people. reviewText: Sinners and Saints is your typical cop with problems stumbles upon something that he shouldn't and is way bigger than he expects, involving professional ex-soldiers/hitmen.  Apart from the movie being based in New Orleans (the "saints" part of the title) you could think of this as really being a poor version of Lethal Weapon 2, with the South African professional hitmen being replaced by Russian mafia hired hitmen.The start of the film is a little weak and it takes you a while to realise just what the story line actually is then it gets better. Sean Patrick Flanery is by no means a bad actor and portrays his role quite well, the same however can't really be said for the other actors (barring Tom Berenger who does well but really only has a bit-part in the movie).In my mind there are various classes of movies, ones that are terrible and just a waste of time so you shouldn't even watch them through ones that OK to watch when nothing else is on to ones that you want to watch again and therefore are worthy of buying the DVD/Blu ray.This falls into the middle category of it's ok to watch if nothing else is on but not really worth buying the DVD. Would be better just to rent.
summary: Not a waste of time but nothing special either
Title: N/A

reviewText: A gritty, cop-action thriller that accomplishes everything it set out to do except make bucks at the box office. This is a straight-to-dvd movie that deserved a better fate. It's a throwback plot with hints of the first "Lethal Weapon" in Johnny Strong's lead cop. He's amazingly good in this. Reviewers may rip the indie flick for breaking no new ground, but it's still a gripping story well-told, well-acted and well-directed. The biggest-name star in the cast (Tom Berenger) sleepwalks through his relatively small role, but everyone else is spot-on. The film's main weakness is that it was released in 2012 instead of 1992, when it wouldn't have had to complete for screen time with all the epic 3D mega-blockbusters.
summary: Surprisingly good

reviewText: Besides Johnny Strong, you can pretty much ignore the featured cast list.  90% of the 'big names' only have a few moments of screen time here.  Kind of like the way they promote 'Car Wash' as a George Carlin and Richard Pryor buddy flick... *cough*Even beyond the lack of stars, the whole film has a very 1996 Fox Television feel to it.  A second rate crime action/thriller with few thrills and way too many shootouts.  Johnny Strong plays a cop who shoots first and asks questions later a la John McClane (Die Hard), but without ANY kind of personality.  He's just a blank slate lobbing dry dialog at other no-name characters with equally uninspired dialog.The gunfights are strong, and come often, but nothing here really lifts 'Sinners and Saints' above the massive pile of these B-movie thrillers.  Not terrible, but also not worth your time.
summary: Subpar at best

reviewText: The present movie bears a great many parallels toLethal Weapon 2.  Like Riggs in LW, the central character is a cop who is a loner & ex Special Forces & he is haunted by his past.  In the present movie, the policemen did a lot of time in both Iraq & Afghanistan.  After doing his part in an attempt to liberate the middle east of terrorists, he is now trying to liberate New Orleans from thugs.Like Riggs in LW, his new partner is an African American who is a family man.  Lastly, the bad guys in the film are also Special Forces dudes whom he is matched-up again.  That said, the bad guys in this film are far more sinister than the ones in LW as they get-off on torturing innocent people to death.For an action flick, the plot of the film was plausible & most of the action scenes were exciting.  It shows a city ravaged by a hurricane whose police force is still trying to put the city back together again.  If you're a fan of the original LETHAL WEAPON, you're almost certain to like this one.
summary: Big trouble in the Big Easy

reviewText: I always wondered how these direct to DVD movies make money and who in the world buys them. I guess my suspicion would be big fans of action movies for whom the Hollywood output is not enough to satisfy their craving. I was a teen in the 80's, the ultimate era of the over the top action theatrical release, so I can imagine fans of that type of movie desiring more than is currently hitting theaters and straight to DVD is the only other option. Action is the raison d'tre for `Sinners and Saints' and action is where it will succeed or fail. So does it succeed? Somewhat.If you love gun battles and watching automatic weapons fire this is the movie for you. The plot involves a large group of ex soldiers, includes the awesome Bas Rutten, searching for the classic McGuffin while torturing people by lighting them on fire extinguishing the fire and then repeating several more times to produce a rather disturbing corpse. It really doesn't matter what they're looking for as it's all just a vehicle to allow for the firing of guns guns guns. On there trail is Detective Sean Riley played by actor Johnny Strong (seriously, according to Wikipedia that's his actual name). Strong is one of those actors with a high likeability factor but his acting is pretty weak and he only seems to know how to project one look, a seething glare. Still, he does a good job of giving the impression of a legitimate tough guy and his one hand to hand action scene is done well.Detective Sean Riley has two great skills. He is amazing with a pistol and twice wins gun battles where he is greatly outnumbered and massively outgunned. But his true talent is that he is impossible to hit. If a half dozen expert shots are spraying his location with bullets they will not hit him. If the main villain is walking towards Riley a few yards away and Riley simply stands in front of him making no attempt to avoid being shot no bullets will find their mark. Riley is helped by the fact that in the `Sinners and Saints' universe bullets cannot penetrate even the thinnest of barriers so if he hides behind a car or the wall of a house he is as safe as someone behind a three foot thick vault door.I have not been a fan of the way modern movies have filmed action scenes with the fast cuts and close up shots. This culminated in Quantum of Solace which was generally an indecipherable blur of movement. Sinners and Saints uses the fast cuts but not to the extent where I can't discern the action. This movie manages the technique correctly whereas Quantum of Solace failed (and it kills me to write that).By and large I thought this was a decent effort for a direct to DVD movie. There are even some moments where the dialogue is quite good and believable particularly in some of the interaction between Riley and his partner Will. I wish it wasn't so repetitious in its use of gun fights but at least they looked good even if they were unrealistic. If I paid to see this movie in the theater I would be disappointed but this isn't a theatrical release so I don't hold it to those standards. Let me finish by saying that Bas Rutten's acting is the best I've seen of any MMA fighter/actor and I wouldn't mind at all seeing him in a larger role in the future.
summary: Piles and Piles of Gun Action

reviewText: "Sinners and Staints;" The DVD "Sinners and Saints" is not the worst movie this year nor is it the best. Like I stated earlier this is just an okay film that is not the best nor the worst I have seen. I would hold out for a repeat of "Cop Out" where I could laugh and see action. It reminded me of kids that like to play cops and robbers or some other type of villain. reviewText: If your itching to see a good cop shoot 'em up, Sinners and Saints is a good prescription for what's ailing you.It has lots of guns and explosions, and plenty of bad guys to count as they go down.Like the protagonist, Sean Riley, of the story, the movie doesn't pull punches. The bad guys are quite a deplorable lot and the movie does a good job of letting you know who Sean is up against. You also know what is at stake and I really was rooting for the good guys.The plot is good, but pretty basic. The trail of clues is interesting as Sean and his partner uncover them, and they fit together.A few times I was confused at what exactly had happened in the events that lead to the movie plot (clues reveal some history), but I could follow along to understand what was going on. It might be the number of times I had to pause the movie (kid not staying in bed) or perhaps it just wasn't clear.The character development is done well. I like the good guys and I don't mind if the bad guys get shot in the face.The action is good, solid, Hollywood guns blazing, window shattering, gun clips of improbable capacity blasting action.There are also plenty of little things in the movie that gave it that level that put it just a bit above the averege.Despite a bit of confusion in the plot details, I enjoyed the movie. It's a solid action movie with characters you can believe in, and lots of guns and a goodly number of explosions.
summary: Saints and Sinners - A cut above the average.

reviewText: "Sinners and Saints" is a film for action film aficionados; it is billed as "A city under siege. A man with nothing to lose. "It has everything folks who enjoy seeing torture, mayhem, violence, bullets, blood, car chases in New Orleans. Frankly, the story was muddled and had something to do with a Russian, a war, drugs, New Orleans Police Department Internal Affairs, but the story never really came through in the film and at the end of the movies, despite watching the "deleted scenes" and "making of the film" on the DVD, I am no nearer understanding what the film was all about. I also must note that at times I found the background music intrusive and annoying. The film is shot in a color reminiscent of earlier Technicolor times. Most of the acting is credible. Taken in its entirety, I could have passed spending time watching it in favor of something less shallow.
summary: Torture, Mayhem, Violence, Bullets, Blood in New Orleans

reviewText: Nothing creative; in fact mostly borrowed from every other movie ever made about cops & drugs on the streets. Too straight black cop; overbearing haggard white cop; beater old car to cruise the streets; eastern European crime moguls with girls and lots of fire power; black drug gang; people getting shot with an arsenal that would embarrass the US military; lots of physical persuasion by cops upon street people. Generally well acted and directed although a little over the top not-believable and too stereotypic. Ending was too predictable and since it was more of the same stuff it just seemed anticlimactic.

reviewText: Maybe because I had never heard anything about this film I had very low expectations.  I read a bunch of positive online reviews which seemed odd because I have never seen one advertisement.  I wasn't familiar with lead Johnny Strong and the rest of the cast is a motley crew of character actors, outside of maybe Tom Berenger and Sean Patrick Flanery.  I was pleasantly shocked that I found myself hooked from the opening battle-royal right through the end.I have never heard of this guy before but this director blew me away.  Like Michael Mann on a shoe-string budget he has talent that shines beyond his limited means.  He pulled no punches, no cgi and all the gun battles, explosions and fights were refreshingly very realistic.  This had the feel of a throw back action film.The story is simple and not too special.  Two cops team up to solve a series of killings in New Orleans.  Turns out one of the cops childhood friends is involved in a military coverup and things begin to tumble out of control. Solid film but not for the faint of heart.  Some intense violence. Strong performances across the board with great turns from home grown favorites Costas  and Louis Mandylor as a baddies.  Cool Method Man, classy Jurgen Prochnow, Jolene Blalock (not seen enough ;)Kevin Phillips, the great Kim Coates and Bas Rutten make this grand buffet of watchable and interesting characters seldom seen in typical low budget fare.  Johnny Strong channels a young Clint Eastwood and helps move this into cult dvd classic range.  Definitely worth checking out if you like this genre!
summary: Completely Surprised.  One of the best indies I have seen this year!

reviewText: Sean Riley, a highly decorated war hero, is a detective for the New Orleans Police Department who is investigating a series of grisly murders.  Professional hit men are torturing their victims by repeating dousing them with gasoline and setting them ablaze.  Riley suspects his wayward brother, Colin, is somehow involved.  As Sean draws closer to discovering the identity of the villain who is ordering the hits, he puts the lives of everyone around him in jeopardy.William Kaufman's "Sinners and Saints" is a gruesome, violent, non-stop action film that kept me in suspense from beginning to end.  Major hunk Johnny Strong (the lead singer for "Operator") stars as Sean Riley, a morose, take-no-prisoners, Dirty Harry-like detective who is a superb killing machine because he has nothing to lose.  His son died of leukemia, his wife abandoned him and his former partner was shot to death during a crack house raid.  Ironically, he's been partnered with Detective Will Ganz (Kevin Phillips) who has the perfect, "Norman Rockwell" family.  Sean's strictly-by-the-books boss, Captain Trahan, is played by the legendary Tom Berenger; he is constantly badgering Riley to follow the rules and not be a loose cannon.  All the leads, especially Strong, gave excellent performances."Sinners and Saints" is a gritty noir that has plenty of explosions, shootouts, fight sequences and car chases.  In other words, it has all the requisites needed for a great action film. However, it also has a tremendous amount of human drama that will pull at your heartstrings.  Sean Riley has experienced a lot of tragedy; his poignant life story has brought tears to my eyes.  "Sinners and Saints" reveals both the good and the bad sides of mankind and the good and the bad that are in each of us.  Sometimes it is difficult to distinguish a sinner from a saint.  In the case of Riley, he is forced to kill in order to prevent his friends from being killed.  However, he sometimes appears a little too keen on massacring all the criminals around him.  He especially takes pleasure in shooting them point blank in the head with their eyes focused on him. Note: In France, the title of this DVD is "Bad Cop."My biggest shock came from Anchor Bay's lack of special features for this film.  Yes, it is presented in widescreen with SDH subtitles.  However, there is not an audio commentary from directors, actors, etc.  There is a very short making of featurette (approximately seven minutes) that is more like a long theatrical trailer; it provides footage of the special effects involved with the car chases and Johnny Strong being coached and prepped for his fighting sequences.  There are also some deleted scenes which are required viewing.  They lack commentary.  After watching them, I understand why some scenes were cut from the final product; however, there are some that should have been left in, especially the one dealing with Internal Affairs and the one involving Johnny being surrounded and abused by a group of professional hit men.Overall, I found "Sinners and Saints" to be a great example of New Orleans noir.  (Despite the lack of special features, the DVD is worth purchasing.)  I'm praying to the saints that there is a sequel.  Sean Riley is my new hero.  He's a wonderful blend of Sylvester Stallone's Lieutenant Marion "Cobra" Cobretti (Cobra [Blu-ray])and Clint Eastwood's Police Inspector Harry "Dirty Harry" Callahan (Dirty Harry Collection (Dirty Harry / Magnum Force / The Enforcer / Sudden Impact / The Dead Pool) [Blu-ray]).  Fans of action thrillers will definitely want to watch "Sinners and Saints."  Be forewarned, the gasoline dousing/igniting torture scenes are rather graphic and disturbing; I cringed while watching them.Joseph B. Hoyos
summary: "Sinners and Saints" is Great New Orleans Noir

reviewText: Sinners And SaintsSinners And Saints brings new meaning to the concept of "Pain"!I would imagine if one has nothing to lose, and there are no gods, all things are absolutely possible?I found Sinners And Saints to be a fantastic philosophical adventure delving into many human concepts such as: good and evil, sinners and saints, either/or questions, and the big question of "Why".Sinners And Saints is non stop (shoot-em-up) action... no nudity (that I remember), no romance, not too much lull talking about the olden-days or the way things could have been.the stage, for Sinners And Saints, is creatively set in New Orleans, Louisiana after the infamous Hurricane Katrina, depicted as realistic, grungy, gritty, grimy and very dangerous, except for the newly rebuilt part of the City which is overly saturated with vibrant colors, plenty of sunshine, leafy trees and singing birds.the "stun grenades", used in Sinners And Saints, are really nice... :)great looking, well built, leading men, a plus in any movie -- if ya ask Me! :)Horrific graphical imagery -- very creative ways to torture or knock people off.Sinners And Saints adds a whole new layer to the meaning of the word 'Pain".  --  some of these images I really didn't need to linger in my brain -- Not for kids, imo. 'nuf said.  Does this sound like Your kind of Movie?  --Highly Recommended!  --Katharena Eiermann, 2012

reviewText: Never having heard of "Sinners and Saints," I can honestly say that my expectations were appropriately grounded. Perhaps that's why the film came as such a pleasant surprise. It's certainly not the best, most professional, or most original movie that you'll see this year--but it works and that's the most important thing. It aims to be exciting and entertaining, and it succeeds at those modest goals without being insultingly idiotic! That's where so many straight-to-DVD endeavors go wrong, they oftentimes miss the point of having a coherent and reasonable screenplay. "Sinners and Saints" is an old school police actioner that has a satisfyingly high body count, a twisty narrative, and likable protagonists. It has plenty of shoot-outs, some gleefully unpleasant torture scenes, and plenty of fisticuffs tied together by an interesting story set in the dilapidated venues of post-Katrina New Orleans.When a series of grisly murders attract the attention of the NOPD brass, a hot-headed but street smart cop (Johnny Strong) is assigned to help the homicide detectives. The deaths appear to be linked to a powerful criminal enterprise, and Strong may have unexpected ties to the murders. His childhood friend (Sean Patrick Flanery) seems to be neck deep in the trouble. The cops spend most of the film trying to track down Flanery to discover just what is motivating this killing spree. Along the way, they become a target themselves and many scenes just end with a ridiculous amount of gunfire. The actual motives really don't matter that much, they just serve as a catalyst to initiate the violence and mayhem. And the action sequences are orchestrated with precision with a good mix of excitement, danger, and over-the-top fun.The movie certainly has its flaws and moments that strain credulity, but I liked it well enough to just go with the flow. Perhaps the biggest plot oversight involves the power player behind the criminal enterprise played by Jurgen Prochnow. The film ends with his story dangling in the wind, unresolved, and never to be mentioned again. I did love the endless supply of machine gun toting henchman that were available throughout the picture, the fact that the ending confrontation didn't arouse the interest of police or any passing cars, and the fact that a major character just showed up randomly at the same confrontation. But despite the expected silliness, the film still kept me involved. I give most of that credit to its lead actor, Johnny Strong. I'm not familiar with Strong, but if this is any indication--I expect I might be seeing him again. Credible as both an action star and in moments that required more character complexity, this guy should have a career. "Sinners and Saints," at the end of the day, may not necessarily be a great movie but it is an effective and enjoyable one. It has relatively modest ambitions, and it succeeds at being the movie that it wants to be. KGHarris, 12/11.
summary: A Surprisingly Effective Old-School Actioner That Deserves To Find A Home Viewing Audience

reviewText: First Blood, Lethal Weapon, Die Hard, all of the first installments from those kinds of franchises get a worthy nod from this action thriller.  The hero, played by the gorgeous Johnny Strong (who also did the music), is a rogue cop.  Who is also a veteran.  Who, by the way, has already lost everything and therefore has. nothing. left. to. lose.  There's a sinister international plot afoot.  And a sane partner who is a family man.  You see where I'm going with this, right?  This movie is exactly what you would expect, right through the closing credits.  But that doesn't make it less awesome.  There's a reason we like these movies.  They speak to our senses of justice and to our feelings (sometimes) that we are alone in a dangerous world.  And everyone in this movie absolutely delivers on those expectations.Sinners and Saints is less garish than its big budget predecessors, and there wasn't a weak link in the cast.  I would have given it five stars except for its waste of New Orleans.  NOLA is a unique place.  If you're going to set your movie there, you should include at least some of the local characteristics that make it special.  This movie could have been set anywhere, save for one tiny plot point.  There's nothing, no music, no people, no lights, no nothing to pin it here except for the NOPD lettering on the bullet proof vests.
summary: Good Addition to the One Man Army Genre
Title: N/A

reviewText: It seems that beleaguered cops that take on criminals who are armed more like terrorists than criminals and then shoot those same criminals are held up to more scrutiny than the bad guys in films these days. A bad guy opens up with a machine gun and a rocket launcher on the police. After a chase, the policeman shoots the bad guy with a .45 and yet the public outcry is for the officer. I know, this is oversimplification but then again we're talking about a movie that may run anywhere from 80 to 120 minutes. The fact is in movies these days the police are often portrayed as more flawed than those they are trying to stop.Such is the case with SINNERS AND SAINTS. Johnny Strong portrays Det. Sean Riley, a New Orleans police officer who is facing major inquiries into his abilities for shooting criminals that shoot first and answer questions later. The movie opens with his partner being killed and another officer shot by a group they came to question. When they return fire and take out the bad guys, guess who might be brought up on charges and taken off the streets? Yep, the police.But there is more going on with Riley than just his partner's death. As the film proceeds we discover he's dealing with the death of his child and a divorce. His long time friend Colin (Sean Patrick Flannery) is completely unaware of this when he shows up out of the blue. They may have grown up together but they took separate paths. Colin always seems to end up in trouble. Before he leaves this time, he presents Riley with a gift that goes unopened.To keep Riley on the force his commander places him with a new partner, a homicide detective named Will Ganz (Kevin Phillips). Ganz is more the usual police detective, wears a suit and tie and digs for clues more often than interrogating suspects. The two would seem a perfect fit and actually do compliment one another. As they begin working together they start investigating a series of murders where the victims are tied to chairs and lit on fire only to have the flames extinguished and started over and over again. It's a particularly cruel form of torture but leads them to realize this isn't about serial killing; this is someone searching for something.As they track down clues and informants Colin's name comes up which puts Riley in a particularly bad situation. True to his duty, he seeks out his old friend with the hope of helping him before those responsible for these torture murders find him first. The clues lead to a group of mercenaries rather than street thugs. And the local street gang that suffered the loss of their leader's brother wants vengeance as well. What secret does Colin have that would cause these mercenaries to search for him?There is a spate of films being released straight to DVD these days from various companies, never making it to the local theater that uses several screens for their one hit film. Some are terrible and others like this one worth seeing. It may not feature a mega-star in the lead role but Strong is a credible actor who is quite believable here. Not only can he act, he handles the action portions of the role fine as well.The story is more believable than most as well. When the reason for the mercenaries search comes out and Colin's ties to it, it seems plausible.The weakest part of the movie is Phillips. He honestly seems to be trying his best but at the same time seems like he is acting rather than just being the role. Perhaps with time he will get past this. Let's hope.On the whole this movie isn't one that will result in repeated viewings but will offer a decent night's entertainment for fans of police stories, mysteries and action films. And with the performance he offers one hopes that Strong will find the perfect vehicle to take him to star status.
summary: BAD TIMES IN THE BIG EASY

reviewText: Ok, so I stumbled upon this film here on Amazon, and after reading all the positive reviews here, i thought i would give it a shot.I was hoping for a real top class action, at least some very good gunfights, but i was really disappointed.the plot was shallow and lame, and the acting was just terrible. It is movies like this that do highlight for me why there are A list actors and there are B list actors, and that not anyone can be a good actor. seriously, acting was atrocious and very amateur acting here.now for the action, there was nothing special about it at all, in fact, it was worse than most action films i have seen. the gunfights were ok to some extent, but many times, it was clear that they relied heavily on CGI. even the bullets hitting the walls were actually CGI.there was poor character development, and i honestly didn't care for the good guys here. did not feel connected.I did feel that the people behind this movie tried hard with decent efforts to make a movie, but they ultimately failed, they lacked the good movie making skills.to summarize, this movie is not worth wasting your time over it, poor acting, boring plot and just about average action scenes with plenty of unrealistic CGI, avoid it.

reviewText: Slow and boring yet gory, Sinners and Saints was so bad that I just had to quit it about 40 minutes into it.  Not because something happened that pushed me over the edge, but really because I just decided I would rather go to the bathroom then didn't want to restart when I came back upstairs.  I can understand an indie drama about lesbians cowboys eating pudding being this slow, but this was supposed to be an action movie and there just wasn't really anything happening for most of the movie.This review may seem counter to the other ones you read here because for the limited time that there was action is was very in your face (and went out of its way to be gory and "shocking"), but that was only in the opening sequence.  After that... nothing for longer than I was willing to watch.  Maybe it got better... maybe it didn't... but you would have to pay me to watch any of it again, so I can't recommend that you spend any money on it.
summary: Completely Surprised... One of the worst movies I have seen in a long time

reviewerName: Michael B. Druxman "A Good Story is a Terribl...
reviewText: SINNERS AND SAINTS is the kind of movie that irks me.It irks me because it's a pretty good cops-and-robbers action movie that, with a little more attention to the screenplay, could have been a hell of a lot better.Despite the fact that there were a couple of moments where I wasn't quite sure who was shooting at who, William Kaufman knows how to direct an exciting action sequence.  Indeed, these scenes are the best part of the picture.And, the story also starts out to be pretty compelling, as two New Orleans detectives, played by Johnny Strong and Kevin Phillips, begin investigating a series of gruesome murders in which the victims were burned alive.  It's soon discovered that the key to solving the mystery rests with a childhood friend of Strong's (Sean Patrick Flanery), a mercenary recently returned from the Middle East.Where the movie goes awry is in its second half.  Suddenly, characters start doing things that seem to have no motivation except for the fact that either the director or screenwriter commanded it.  Even the well-staged action sequences in the latter part of the picture fall flat.  They appear to be there for their own sake, rather than furthering the story.There also seems to be a never-ending supply of disposable bad guys whose only purpose in the movie is to show up, shoot hundreds of bullets at the hero, then get killed.  Their on-going presence reminds me of the ads for a 1950s science-fiction movie: "Kill One and Two Take Its Place!"The cast, which includes Kim Coates and Tom Berenger in cameo roles, is competent, and the film provides many views of New Orleans not often seen on screen.The DVD from Anchor Bay Entertainment includes some deleted scenes. Michael B. Druxman
summary: This One Could Have Been Better
Title: N/A

reviewerName: Michelle L. Beck "Always the Devourer of Good...
reviewText: Sean Riley (Johnny Strong), a New Orleans Detective with no fear, has been in so many gunfights in the last four months that the department is starting to wonder how safe the criminals are with Riley on the street. Having recently lost his son to leukemia, and mourning the end of his marriage, Riley has turned to his work and bringing down the bad guys to soothe his soul. Working on a series of grisly murders perpetrated by some merciless killers with fellow Detective Will Gantz (Kevin Phillips), the two follow the clues where they lead. To complicate matters, Riley's friend, Colin (Sean Patrick Flanery), a mercenary and general screw-up, had made a sudden appearance. Colin is center in the middle of whatever is going on. Apparently, he is in possession of something that a bad guy, Raymond Crowe (Costas Mandylor) wants, and who will stop at nothing to get it back. Afterall Crowe has a secret, and is willing to silence all witnesses to keep it that way.Overall, I really liked Sinners & Saints. It was gritty and offered tons of entertainment. There were tons gunfights, lots of trash talk, a cocaine snorting bad guy, and a handsome leading man. The acting was decent (Tom Berenger is still solid as a rock) and I loved the gritty cinematography. And the only somewhat annoying thing about the movie was Gantz's character. There were times that he seemed to whine and I personally wanted him to "man up" and get in the game (and when he eventually takes some sort of stand, you will roll your eyes). But eventually you overlook his faults because you realize that Riley's character was strong because he had some life experiences (the military, his wife's departure and his son's premature death) that solidified his fearless personality, while Gantz was just "what he was" (a rookie detective who really had not been in the mist of action and had a lot to lose). Therefore, Strong's nothing to lose, yet sympathetic and brooding persona, definitely outshined those irritants and made this an entertaining and highly enjoyable movie.  I give it a 4.5 or 5.
summary: More Saint than Sinner.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This movie isn't shy at all when it comes to showing its "influences."It has shades ofDirty Harry(tough, violent cop takes out tough, violent bad guys in a tough, violent manner, and is warned by his Captain (a less-than-healthy-looking Tom Berenger) that if he "goes too far to the dark side he may not find his way back"),Lethal Weapon("Emotionally scarred" loner cop teams with more stable cop with pretty wife and great kids, and even though he's drawn to the sense of family, he MUST keep hos emotional distance), Michael Madsen's sick, twisted malevolence fromReservoir Dogs, virtually every Steven Seagal film you've ever seen, especially with the inclusion of Russian Mob characters, and in terms of cinematography, FX Network's legendary seriesThe Shield: Complete Series. And as if that's not enough, it's set in a post-Hurricane Katrina New Orleans, with characters making reference to "bodies floating by and no one cared" and sharing about how they would rather live in downtown Baghdad than the Big Easy.Of course, like every other bowl of gumbo, you'd better plan on chewing a few mouthfuls of slimy okra before you hit the bottom of THIS bowl.The film WANTS star Jimmy Strong to be a memorable and dynamic lead figure, but the elaborate tattoos, close-cropped beard and consistently deadpan, moody demeanor just add up to "I've seen this all before, and when I saw it before, it was done better."Five minutes into the movie, your're knee-deep into the first semiautomatic weapon gun battle. They whip these out every ten to fifteen minutes throughout the film, especially when the paper-thin plot begins to sag. The characters jump from gun battles to exposition, rather than letting the events of the film unfold naturally, so that when you hear the sound of gunfire, you breathe a sigh of relief and think "at least he stopped talking for five minutes."It's sad to see Tom Berenger in the film. He just doesn't look well at all. I know he's no longer a youngster, but I can't tell if his appearance is due to illness, plastic surgery, or both. He just doesn't look or sound good at all (although his character IS supposed to be a "grizzled veteran" of the N'awlins PD...maybe it's secretly an Oscar-worthy performance with great makeup. I personally think he looks like he's under the weather).The bad guys take Michael Madsen's riff from "Reservoir Dogs" and run with it, to new levels of sick extreme. Will it turn you off or make you want to watch the film a second time? You'll know when you see it.Even though the box art carries the four star, "An Outstanding Action Thriller" recommendation from "Film Threat," if I wanted that kind of entertainment, I'd probably head to my all-time favorite, the Brian Bosworth / Lance Henriksen biker epicStone Cold, or maybe the aforementioned Lethal Weapon series, or Die Hard, or...And when the movie ends, it's hard to care. The screenwriters / director do their best to wrap a tidy little bow around the preceding 104 minutes but it's very, very hard to care. I'd have to say that this was a mildly amusing film to watch once, but for this kind of entertainment, you have FAR too many other choices...likeSteven Seagal Collection: 4 Film Favorites - Under Siege / The Glimmer Man / Above the Law / Fire Down Below, for instance.Caveat Emptor.
summary: Imagine a Steven Seagal movie without Steven Seagal...

reviewText: I was prepared to really downgrade this film, but it caught me from the beginning. reviewText: I must admit I didn't know a thing about this movie and I took a flyer on this."Sinners and Saints" (104 min.) brings a complicated storyline that remains pretty unclear (to me) until late in the movie, I mean I really had a really hard time figuring out or understanding exactly what was exactly going on. That is not a good thing for a movie (maybe I am just slow). But fortunately there is PLENTY of action, shoot-out scenes in particular. The other thing I really enjoyed about the movie is the New Orleans scenery, where this movie is set. Lots of gorgeous overhead shots of the New Orleans downtown and the surrounding areas. Johnny Strong brings a gritty performance as the main character, and Tom Berenger (in a much smaller supporting role) is also quite good as his superior.The other thing (already mentioned by several other reviewers) is that the overall tone of the movie reminded me of previous Michael Mann-directed "dark" crime dramas, which is a plus. It's unfortunate that the actual storyline leaves to be desired. In all, recommened for anyone looking for an action movie while not minding too much the underlying story.
summary: Check it out for the shoot-out scenes and the New Orleans scenery

reviewText: Sinners and Saints delivers what it promises on the back cover.  There are some good cameo performances, the shootouts are kickin' and Johnny Strong has a certain screen presence and believable charisma. reviewText: Johnny Strongis Sean Riley, a New Orleans cop, a sort-of poor man'sDirty Harry. His son has died, and his wife has left him. Oh, and his partner's been killed in a shootout. So Riley has little interest in going bythe book). He soon has a new partner (Kevin Phillips), and the two are assigned to investigate a series of grisly murders. The murders lead to a gang investigation, a potential gang war, and perhaps even a military conspiracy.The plot, consisting of hackneyed tropes that we've seen many times before, is pretty much a pretext for a lot of gunplay and macho posturing along the lines of "If you touch my family, I'll kill you." That's not to say this film is awful. It's not. But it's nothing new either. There are nice touches here and there and a particularly violent and sadistic means of torture, but there are numerous missed opportunities along the way that make the film pretty much a must-see for only die-hard action fans. For me, though, it was just a way to pass 90 minutes.
summary: No shortage of testosterone

reviewText: Sinners & Saints suggests a storyline built around redemption. But it never delivers, unless you believe that violence is a solution. This movie is filled with talented actors, great special effects and lots of artistic talent. It seems like the idea was to try to produce the next big action hero a la Clint Eastwood of the 21st century. Our hero even appears to cultivate his persona, complete with Gran Torino (if I'm not mistaken, this was his car). The story is promising but not quite complete. There are threads of building intrigue through the script and images. But it all goes nowhere. The dialogue is difficult to understand with excessive expletives and the need for editing. All of the gratuitous violence results in a wreckage of a movie with no redeeming social value. This movie is a waste of talent to me but if you enjoy mindless violence, you will love this movie.
summary: Great for Lovers of Violence
Title: N/A

reviewText: I had some high hopes for this movie after reading some reviews on it. Unfortunately, it falls far short of expectations. There are so many things wrong with the movie, I don't even know where to begin. The movie is basically a take-off of Lethal Weapon, with many scenes taken right from that movie. A burnt out cop with nothing to lose and a habit of getting into trouble (Johnny Strong) is paired with a new partner (Kevin Phillips), a black man with a warm loving family, who just want to make it through each day. They must solve a case where people are being burned to death as an 'interrogation' technique by the main villain, who's searching for a video tape.75% of the actors in the movie either didn't take it seriously or just couldn't act. I've never seen Kevin Phillips in any other movie, so I can't attest to his acting skills, however he was AWFUL in this movie. A huge number of the smaller rolls were clearly given to people without a shred of acting experience... it wasn't just 'raw', it was terrible. This leaves the remaining 25% of the actors who either could act or at least tried to act, seem ridiculously out of place in this movie. I was actually embarrassed watching Johnny Strong try to deliver heart-felt lines about his son. It was actually painful to watch. There were also various scenes where they clearly tried to have an 'epic' moment between the villain and good guy... a sit down where they both speak to each other candidly. Think Robert De Niro and Al Pacino in 'Heat', or Christopher Walken and Dennis Hopper in 'True Romance'. This movie, however, tried at least three times to pull it off, yet it came across terribly each time. The dialog was just stupid, and it was delivered badly.Editing and special effects were also awful. I understand it's a low-budget film, but it was so blatantly obvious in just about every scene in the movie. The action scenes all took place in clearly run-down and abandoned areas, where shooting up a house would be cheapest. There was also a laughable scene where it seemed they merged the morgue with the police department set... like they rolled the corpse to the chief's office. At one point they had a torture scene that should have been horrific, where one of the villains set a man on fire, extinguished him, the re-set him on fire over and over again, to 'scare' another man into talking. Between the poor acting, terrible fire special effects, cheap props, and strange editing effects, my wife and I actually burst out laughing. The scene, which was suppose to be gruesome and scary, was hysterically bad.Another thing to point out is that even the soundtrack was bad... many of the scenes had music played over it that was awkwardly out of place. This was the final touch that made the movie seem like a complete mess. There were numerous scenes that were clearly taken straight from 'Lethal Weapon'... so much so, that I found it annoying. Lastly, the 'suspension of disbelief' that was required to sit through this movie was almost obscene... in one scene, the villain is racing down the street in a car and our two 'heroes' manage to run fast enough to get in front of him... but then, instead of shooting at the car from behind another car, or from the sidewalk, our brilliant heroes stand next to each other in the middle of the street, directly in front of this speeding vehicle, and try to shoot the driver. It doesn't work, as the car plows straight through them and sends them both hurtling through the air. Luckily, the two stumble to their feet, with little more then bruises and cuts. This movie was just plain awful...
summary: Awful
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a surprisingly good action movie.  People are being killed in gruesome ways for reasons that are not immediately understood.  Eventually, it becomes clear that some very bad people are trying to recover a videotape that shows a cold-blooded killing of military personnel by some other military people, although it is never made known why it ever happened in the first place or why the tape was made.  Much of the action involves the bad guys killing people who stand in their way of recovering that tape.  The person who possesses the tape turns out to be a friend of the protagonist of the movie, Sean Riley, who is a very tough New Orleans cop.  Riley is on the verge of suspension for all the people he has killed while dispensing his own brand of street justice.  He makes Dirty Harry seem like a wimp by comparison.  The bad guys make the mistake of killing the brother of a very dangerous gang leader who seeks revenge, which puts an interesting twist in the story that could have been developed more.  Most of the action involves Riley's attempts to stop the killers and prevent his friend from being killed.  The action is graphic, brutal, and almost non-stop.The main problem with this movie is the story is poorly-developed.  The reason for the mysterious tape is never really explained. The main villain has a deadline to deliver the tape to his boss, but there is never any explanation as to who his boss is, why he would care about the tape, and why the military people were executed in the first place.  There are some gun battles that are just not at all believable.  Villains who are supposed to be highly-trained ex-military men are seemingly incapable of killing Riley with machine guns while he dispatches them with ease with his service pistol in several scenes.  In another scene Riley and his partner are hit head-on by a speeding car yet both remain not only alive but are also able to get back up and walk as though they were only bruised up a little bit.  There is a lot of gritty, sadistic violence that may be offensive to some people.Fans of action movies with lots of violence who really don't care about a realistic or meaningful story will probably like this movie.  Sean Riley is a great action hero, and a sequel would be welcome with a better screenplay to flesh out the story and characters better.
summary: plenty of action, not much story
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Sinners and Saints" is an action thriller that takes place in a post-Katrina New Orleans.  As leader of an elite street crimes task force squad, Detective Sean Reilly (Johnny Strong) is trying to cope with the death of his young son and the abandonment of his wife.  When a routine warrant service results in an ambush and the vicious murder of his partner, this might be the last straw for Sean.  Reassigned by his mentor, Capt. Trahan (Tom Berenger), Sean and Det. Will Ganz (Kevin Phillips) investigate a baffling gangland homicide.As the clues pile up, Sean and Will realize that Colin (Sean Patrick Flanery), one of Sean's childhood friends, and a security contractor just back from the Middle East, seems to be at the center of the horrible case.  The two quickly realize there is something far more sinister going on than either could ever have imagined.Though director William Kaufman incorporates many familiar elements into this cop thriller, he manages to transcend mere cliche and has crafted an exciting picture.  Location filming on the ravaged streets of New Orleans give the movie a gritty tone.  Be warned: many scenes in this strong R-rated feature are graphically violent.  Blu-ray special features include a behind-the-scenes making-of featurette and deleted scenes.
summary: Post-Katrina New Orleans Thriller
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a film by writer and director Will Kaufman (`The Prodigy') set in the seedy underworld of New Orleans and stars Johnny Strong (`The Fast and the Furious' and `Black Hawk Down') as Detective Sean Riley. He has a marriage that has gone south after the untimely death of his son through cancer, he is not afraid to break the rules and survives on his wits and prescription drugs. Basically he is a `cop on the edge' and I don't mean the guitarist from U2.It kicks off as it means to go on with a full on shoot out involving some low life types who are holed up in a clap board house - and like the There Little Pigs, they should have gone for bricks, as all hell breaks loose. His partner gets hit and post shoot out he is paired up with Detective Will Gantz - Kevin Phillips (`Notorious'). Things take a turn for the nasty when a series of brutal torture slayings start to happen. Add to the mix Sean's old army buddy, Colin (Sean Patrick Flannery of `The Boondock Saints' - cult classic) who lets them know this is more than they can handle. As a full scale gang war kicks off things then really start to heat up. We also have Internal Affairs looking into some questionable tactics that Riley may have used in the past.Where this really scores though is the action, it is done realistically and has a bullet count that `The A Team' would have been proud of, but these bullets actually do hit their targets. The acting is all top rate if a tad sensational at points, the clichés are all believable and the special effects really work. For movie anoraks also spot the bar they use is called The Boondock saint as an homage to Sean Patrick Flannery and that film, which is a must se by the way.This then is 100 minutes of cop action, released as `Bad Cop' in the UK, where the stereo types line up to be counted and are not found wanting, Will Kaufman has done a really good job of getting the most from the actors and from a less than original script and it all really works. - this may be far from genre breaking but I think it is genre enhancing.
summary: Guns, Violence, Bullets, Torture, Lead and Guns all set in Mofo Orleans!
Title: N/A

reviewText: "This is N'Awlins white boy, you ain't seen nothing' yet." After a call goes horribly bad Detective Sean Riley (Strong) is given a new partner. Trying to cope with a failed marriage, the death of his son, and a series of brutal murders that is affecting the entire city he is a very unstable officer. When clues lead to something bigger then either expected it is up to the two new partners to work together and stop the ring before it's too late. Lately the "cop revenge" movies have been very slow and not exciting to watch (Blood Out/Set Up). This one, while slow in parts, is very good. I tried as hard as I could not to compare the two, but this one reminded me of a harsher "Lethal Weapon". There really is nothing new in this movie. A loose cannon of a detective is teamed with a family man who is by the book, the two somehow can work together and yada...yada...yada. Even though this is a movie that has been done to death it is still very enjoyable and very much worth watching. I really enjoyed it. Overall, one of the few repetitive type movies that is exciting and worth a watch. I give it a B+.
summary: Even though this type of movie has been done a million times this is a very good movie that is worth a watch. I say B+
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Sinners and Saints" is a violent action flick taking place in a post-Katrina New Orleans overrun with organized crime.  It's not really outstanding film in an already overstuffed film genre, but it will no doubt please action genre fans and does an impressive job of maximizing it's small budget with very high production values.The story focuses on the classic "man with nothing left to lose", in this case a police officer whose aggressive tactics (and bad luck) land him in hot water with Internal Affairs as he investigates a set of particularly cruel gangland murders.  The cast is surprisingly solid in spite of the names most likely to generate interest (rapper Method Man, MMA legend Bas Rutten, sizzling hot Jolene Blalock, and Sean Patrick Flanery of Boondock Saints) having tiny roles.  While I'm still waiting for Bas to get a leading role and become the new Van Damme (seriously, watch an episode of Punk Payback and tell me that dude shouldn't be a star) Johnny Strong and Kevin Phillips keep an otherwise over-the-top action flick very down to earth with believable everyman performances as the film's leads.  Strong's character's protectiveness of his partner's perfect family life is rocking some bromance vibes, but it's never portrayed as sappy so much as a man seeking to vicariously protect what he has already lost himself.  That's something I think most of us will be able to relate to on some level, and it's part of what makes this film a bit better than an average straight-to-dvd action movie.Now, I'm not a huge fan of buddy cop flicks or crime movies, but I enjoyed Sinners and Saints in spite of that fact.  The violence here is plentiful, the performances are good, and the story is interesting if not exceptionally well-told.  All in all, it's a fun cops vs criminals movie to kill an hour and a half with -especially if you are a fan of the genre- and shouldn't really disappoint so long as you aren't looking for the next Pulp Fiction.
summary: Solid if unexceptional renegade cop flick.

reviewText: This movie surprised me. It had a good story line, great action scenes & decent characters. For anyone that has seen the Lethal Weapon movies, you will see a similarity in the characters. Crazy white cop with nothing to lose, family oriented black cop with a lot to lose. Throw in some serious bad guys and shoot outs and you have yourself a great action movie! Definitely recommend!
summary: Decent action flick
